title: Bradshaw Mountains
text:
The Bradshaw Mountains (, "rough, black range of rocks") are a <a href="mountain%20range">mountain range</a> in central <a href="Arizona">Arizona</a>, United States, named for brothers Isaac and <a href="William%20D.%20Bradshaw">William D. Bradshaw</a> after their deaths, having been formerly known in English as the Silver Mountain Range.
History.
The first known settlements in the Bradshaws were a group of <a href="Yavapai%20people">Yavapai people</a>, called the <a href="Kwevkapaya">Kwevkapaya</a> who built forts and mined <a href="copper">copper</a> from around AD 1100 to 1600.
The Walker party found gold, and within a few years, the Bradshaws were filling up with settlers mining for gold, silver, and copper. In the early part of the 20th century, most of the towns that had sprung up were little more than <a href="ghost%20town">ghost town</a>s.
Geography.
Located approximately 5 miles (8 km) south of <a href="Prescott%2C%20Arizona">Prescott, Arizona</a>, between the <a href="Agua%20Fria%20River">Agua Fria River</a> on the east, and the <a href="Hassayampa%20River">Hassayampa River</a> on the west, the range is 40 miles (64 km) long, and almost 25 miles (40 km) wide.
Geology.
The Bradshaw Mountains consist primarily of <a href="Precambrian">Precambrian</a> <a href="granite">granite</a>, <a href="gneiss">gneiss</a> and <a href="schist">schist</a>.
Ecology.
The biotic community of the Bradshaws ranges from <a href="Chaparral">interior chaparral</a> and montane conifer forest, to plains and <a href="Grassland%23Xeric%20grasslands">desert grassland</a>, and Sonoran desert <a href="Scrubland">scrub</a>. Many species of trees are found in the Bradshaws, including <a href="Pinyon%20pine">Piñon</a>, <a href="Juniperus%20deppeana">Alligator Juniper</a>, <a href="Ponderosa%20pine">Ponderosa pine</a>, <a href="Blue%20Spruce">Blue Spruce</a>, <a href="Quaking%20Aspen">Quaking Aspen</a>, <a href="White%20fir">White fir</a>, and <a href="Douglas%20fir">Douglas fir</a>. As well, much wildlife is present, including <a href="javelina">javelina</a>, <a href="mountain%20lion">mountain lion</a>, <a href="bobcat">bobcat</a>, <a href="American%20black%20bear">black bear</a>, <a href="mule%20deer">mule deer</a>, <a href="porcupine">porcupine</a>, <a href="fox">fox</a>, <a href="skunk">skunk</a>, <a href="abert%27s%20squirrel">abert's squirrel</a>, <a href="rock%20squirrel">rock squirrel</a>, <a href="wild%20turkey">wild turkey</a>, many species of reptiles and amphibians, and many species of birds.
Several creeks have been dammed to form <a href="reservoir">reservoir</a>s, including <a href="Lynx%20Lake%20%28Arizona%29">Lynx Lake</a>, <a href="Goldwater%20Lake">Goldwater Lake</a>, <a href="Lake%20Marapai">Lake Marapai</a>, <a href="Hassayampa%20Lake">Hassayampa Lake</a>, <a href="Horsethief%20Lake">Horsethief Lake</a>, and <a href="Cedar%20Tank">Cedar Tank</a>.
Human use.
<a href="Gold">Gold</a> was first discovered in the Bradshaws in 1863, over $2,000,000 worth being taken from just the Crown King Mine. Copper and <a href="silver">silver</a> were also mined in the early part of the 20th century. Within Mount Union lies the Poland Junction silver mine. Its adit, now sealed, may be accessed from <a href="Poland%20Junction%2C%20Arizona">Poland Junction</a>, near <a href="Walker%2C%20Arizona">Walker</a>.
Ghost towns and other settlements.
There are over 40 <a href="ghost%20towns">ghost towns</a> in the Bradshaw Mountains, including <a href="Crown%20King%2C%20Arizona">Crown King</a>, <a href="Bumble%20Bee%2C%20Arizona">Bumble Bee</a>, <a href="Goodwin%2C%20Arizona">Goodwin</a>, <a href="Bradshaw%20City%2C%20Arizona">Bradshaw City</a>, <a href="Alexandra%2C%20Arizona">Alexandra</a> and <a href="Cleator%2C%20Arizona">Cleator</a>.
Protected areas.
Much of the Bradshaw Mountains are on <a href="Prescott%20National%20Forest">Prescott National Forest</a> land. Other parks include Horsethief Basin Recreational Area, <a href="Lynx%20Lake%20%28Arizona%29">Lynx Lake Recreational Area</a>, and the <a href="Castle%20Creek%20Wilderness">Castle Creek Wilderness</a>.
